questions.text: Which of the following placental factors can lead to obstetric inversion of the uterus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Uterine inversion is a rare but life-threatening obstetric emergency where the uterus turns inside out, usually following delivery. It is most commonly associated with excessive traction on the umbilical cord or fundal pressure when the uterus is atonic. Certain placental factors can predispose to inversion due to abnormal adherence or location of the placenta.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Placenta previa (Option A):

In this condition, the placenta is located near or covering the cervical os. It can cause antepartum hemorrhage, but it is not typically associated with uterine inversion, as the placenta is low-lying and does not exert traction on the uterine fundus.

Placental abruption (Option B):

This refers to premature separation of a normally implanted placenta. It can cause concealed or revealed bleeding but does not lead to uterine inversion because the placenta separates prematurely and usually does not remain adherent to cause fundal traction.

Placenta accreta (Option C):

This is a condition where the placenta is abnormally adherent to the myometrium and fails to separate properly after delivery. If excessive cord traction is applied in an attempt to deliver such a placenta, it can lead to pulling the uterine fundus inward, causing uterine inversion. This is the most relevant placental factor associated with inversion.

questions.text: Degree of uterine inversion in following figure:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows a mass visible in the vaginal canal, resembling the uterine fundus. The cervix appears inverted and stretched, allowing the fundus to descend into the vagina, but not protruding beyond the vulva. The mass may resemble a soft, smooth structure with or without the attached placenta, depending on the stage at which inversion was recognized.

This is characteristic of a second-degree (complete) uterine inversion, where the fundus has completely passed through the cervix, but has not yet emerged outside the vulval opening.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

First degree (Option A):

In this stage, the fundus is indented but has not passed through the cervix. The uterus appears slightly depressed on ultrasound or palpation, but no mass is visible in the vagina. The image clearly shows a mass in the vaginal canal, so this stage is ruled out.

Third degree (Option C):

In this stage, the inverted uterus protrudes outside the vulva, and is visible externally. The image does not show any structure emerging out of the vulva, so third-degree inversion is not supported.

Fourth degree (Option D):

This is the most severe form, where both the uterus and vaginal walls are inverted and are seen outside the introitus. The image lacks evidence of external protrusion of both structures, making this option incorrect.

choices.text: Removal of placenta followed by repositioning of uterus
Attempt to reposition uterus with placenta in situ

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida patient delivered vaginally after a spontaneous labor. After delivery placenta did not deliver spontaneously so the obstetrician attempted controlled cord traction. During the procedure the obstetrician noticed a pear shaped mass protruding outside with a broad base pointing downwards and placenta attached to it. The next best step in management of such patient:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical scenario describes acute uterine inversion, a rare but life-threatening obstetric emergency that typically presents immediately after delivery, often during or after controlled cord traction when the placenta is still attached.

In acute uterine inversion, the first priority is immediate manual repositioning of the uterus (e.g., Johnson maneuver), even before removing the placenta, because:

  • Attempting to remove the placenta first may worsen hemorrhage and shock.
  • Repositioning the uterus restores uterine tone and reduces ongoing bleeding.

Clinical Features:

Symptoms:

  • Sudden onset of lower abdominal or pelvic pain
  • Heavy vaginal bleeding
  • Dizziness or collapse due to hypovolemic shock

Signs:

  • Absent uterine fundus on abdominal palpation
  • Smooth, red-blue mass protruding through the vagina (often with placenta attached)
  • Fundal dimple or depression in lower abdomen

Management:

1. Immediate Resuscitation:

  • Secure airway, breathing, and circulation (ABC)
  • High-flow oxygen
  • Large bore IV access, start fluid resuscitation
  • Crossmatch and prepare blood products

2. Manual Repositioning (Johnson Maneuver):

  • Use the palm and fingers to push the uterine fundus upward through the vagina toward the umbilicus
  • Maintain steady pressure until the uterus reverts to its normal position
  • Do not remove the placenta before repositioning

3. If Manual Reposition Fails:

  • Administer tocolytics to relax uterus (e.g., nitroglycerin, terbutaline)
  • Attempt repositioning again
  • Once successful, administer uterotonics (oxytocin, misoprostol) to promote contraction and prevent recurrence

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Transvaginal ultrasound (Option A):

Useful for diagnosis in subacute or chronic inversion, but not appropriate when the diagnosis is clinically obviousand urgent intervention is needed.

Hysterectomy (Option B):

Considered only when manual and surgical repositioning fails or there's irreversible uterine damage or necrosis. It is not the next step.

Removal of placenta followed by repositioning (Option C):

Contraindicated initially. Removing the placenta first can cause catastrophic hemorrhage. Always attempt repositioning first.

questions.text: Which of the following is a non-surgical method for replacement of uterine inversion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

O'Sullivan's method is a non-surgical (hydrostatic) technique used to correct uterine inversion. It involves the instillation of warm sterile saline or fluid into the vagina using a pressure system (e.g., sigmoidoscope or infusion set) to build up pressure within the vaginal canal. The pressure helps push the inverted uterus back through the cervix into its normal position.

  • It is particularly useful in subacute cases where manual replacement has failed and before resorting to surgery.
  • Requires that the cervix is not tightly constricted, and the vaginal walls are sealed to maintain fluid pressure.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Huntington Procedure (Option B):

This is a surgical method. During laparotomy, the round ligaments are grasped and the uterus is gently pulled upward from the abdominal cavity to restore normal position.

Haultain Method (Option C):

Another surgical procedure, used when the cervical ring is too tight. A posterior incision is made on the cervix to allow repositioning of the uterus manually.

McDouglas Procedure (Option D):

This option is incorrect because there is no recognized method called "McDouglas Procedure" for uterine inversion. It may be a confusion with the pouch of Douglas, but it is not a known method for uterine repositioning.

choices.text: Cupping of fundus in per abdomen examination

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman has just delivered a baby vaginally. Shortly after delivery of the placenta, she develops sudden severe lower abdominal pain and collapses. On examination, the uterus is not palpable abdominally, and a red, smooth mass is seen protruding through the vagina. She is in hypovolemic shock. Which of the following is NOT a feature of this condition ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The diagnosis in this case is Uterine Inversion. Reduction in fundal height is not a feature of uterine inversion. In fact, in uterine inversion, the fundus disappears from its normal position and may be felt as a dimple or cupping on abdominal examination. There is no upward contraction of the uterus that would cause a genuine "reduction" in height. Rather, the uterus is no longer identifiable in the expected position because it has inverted and descended, sometimes even through the cervix or vagina.

Risk Factors for Uterine Inversion

  • Uterine atony
  • Manual removal of placenta
  • Grand multiparity
  • Rapid or precipitous labor
  • Use of uterine relaxants (e.g., magnesium sulfate, halogenated anesthetics)
  • History of previous uterine inversion
  • Congenital uterine anomalies

Clinical Features of Uterine Inversion

  • Profuse vaginal bleeding
  • Collapse or syncope due to sudden blood loss and vagal stimulation
  • Uterine fundus not palpable per abdomen (a key finding)
  • Cupping or dimple felt in place of the fundus on abdominal examination
  • Smooth, red-purple mass protruding through the cervix or vagina (complete inversion)
  • Signs of shock out of proportion to visible blood loss

Degrees (Classification) of Uterine Inversion

  • First Degree (Incomplete):
    • Fundus is inverted but remains within the uterine cavity.
  • Second Degree (Complete):
    • Fundus passes through the cervix but remains inside the vagina.
  • Third Degree (Prolapsed):
    • Inverted uterus protrudes outside the vulva.
  • Fourth Degree (Total Inversion):
    • Both uterus and vaginal walls are inverted and lie outside the introitus.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Cupping of fundus in per abdomen examination (Option A):

Seen in partial inversion. The uterine fundus appears as a dimple or depression, not in its usual position.

Mass protruding outside vulva (Option C):

Seen in complete uterine inversion. The mass may include the uterus with or without the placenta attached.

Neurogenic shock (Option D):

Seen in Uterine Inversion. When the cord is pulled while placenta is still attached there is parasympathetic nerve stretching leading to Neurogenic shock.

choices.text: Occurs exclusively in classical caesarean section
Separation of all three uterine layers with intact amniotic membrane
Uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity becomes continuous

questions.text: Which of the following is a feature of scar dehiscence?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Scar dehiscence refers to the partial separation of a previous uterine scar, usually from a prior cesarean section, in which the serosal layer remains intact and there is no communication between the uterine and peritoneal cavities.

Since the amniotic sac often remains intact, and the separation is usually incomplete, the bleeding is minimal or sometimes absent. It is often detected incidentally during repeat cesarean sections.

Explanation of Incorrect options:

Occurs exclusively in classical caesarean section (Option A):

Scar dehiscence is not exclusive to classical cesarean sections. It can occur with lower segment cesarean scars as well. However, the risk is higher with classical (vertical) scars due to the less muscular and more vascular location.

Separation of all three uterine layers with intact amniotic membrane (Option B):

This describes a complete uterine rupture, not dehiscence. In rupture, there is separation of all three layers(endometrium, myometrium, and serosa). The amniotic sac is typically not intact in rupture.

Uterine cavity and peritoneal cavity becomes continuous (Option C):

This is the hallmark of uterine rupture, where there is complete tear, and the contents of the uterus may spill into the peritoneal cavity, leading to massive hemorrhage and fetal compromise. In scar dehiscence, this continuity does not exist.

choices.text: History of manual removal of placenta

questions.text: Primary uterine rupture can occur due to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Primary uterine rupture refers to uterine rupture without a previous lower segment cesarean scar or any overt uterine trauma in the current pregnancy. However, it may still occur in patients with other types of uterine surgeries or manipulations.

All three listed options are valid risk factors for uterine rupture

Risk Factors of Uterine Rupture

A. Obstetric History-Related:

  • Previous classical cesarean section (vertical incision on upper segment)
  • Previous lower segment cesarean section (especially with short inter-delivery interval)
  • History of uterine rupture in prior pregnancy
  • Previous myomectomy (especially full-thickness or multiple fibroid removal)
  • Previous metroplasty (e.g., Strassman procedure)
  • History of manual removal of placenta
  • History of dilation and curettage (D&C) leading to uterine trauma

B. Labor and Delivery-Related:

  • Induction or augmentation of labor with oxytocin
  • Use of prostaglandins (e.g., misoprostol)
  • Obstructed labor or cephalopelvic disproportion (CPD)
  • Prolonged labor
  • High parity (grand multipara)
  • Forceps or vacuum-assisted delivery
  • Malpresentation (e.g., transverse lie)

C. Uterine Factors:

  • Congenital uterine anomalies
  • Thin lower uterine segment (on ultrasound in late pregnancy)
  • Overdistended uterus (e.g., polyhydramnios, multiple gestation, macrosomia)

D. Miscellaneous:

  • Trauma to the uterus (e.g., motor vehicle accident, fall)
  • External cephalic version (ECV) attempts
  • Short interpregnancy interval (<18 months) after cesarean section

choices.text: Injury to bladder along the line of uterine rupture
Avulsion of cervix from vaginal wall
Detachment of bladder from uterovesical pouch
Cervical laceration along with vaginal tears

questions.solution:
Explanation:

Colporrhexis refers to the avulsion (tearing away) of the cervix from the vaginal vault. It is a rare but serious obstetric injury typically occurring due to violent labor, obstructed labor, or instrumental delivery.

This results in the separation of the cervix from its normal attachment to the vaginal fornices, leading to severe hemorrhage and potential pelvic organ damage.

Explanation of incorrect options:

Injury to bladder along the line of uterine rupture (Option A):

This is more consistent with a complication of uterine rupture, especially when the rupture extends anteriorly. It is not the definition of colporrhexis.

Detachment of bladder from uterovesical pouch (Option C):

This describes a bladder injury or separation from its uterine attachment, which may occur during cesarean or obstructed labor, but it is not colporrhexis.

Cervical laceration along with vaginal tears (Option D):

These are tears involving the cervical canal and vaginal mucosa, often seen in instrumental or precipitous delivery. However, colporrhexis specifically refers to the avulsion of the cervix from the vaginal wall, not just surface tears.

choices.text: Manual removal of placenta under GA

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravida patient was admitted to the labor room with labor pain. During the second stage of labor she was exhausted so the obstetrician performed forceps delivery. Immediately after delivery she started bleeding with tachycardia and hypotension. Placenta did not deliver and there was shortening of umbilical cord. Obstetrician attempted manual removal of the placenta but could not reach the placental attachment. What would be the best step in management of this patient after initial resuscitation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The findings are classic for uterine rupture, particularly a posterior or concealed rupture where the placenta remains within the uterus but the cavity is no longer accessible due to uterine wall disruption. In such cases, laparotomy is the definitive management step after initial stabilization (IV fluids, blood products, and monitoring). Surgical exploration allows confirmation of uterine rupture, control of hemorrhage, delivery of any remaining fetal or placental tissues, and repair (or hysterectomy if needed).

The clinical clues strongly pointing to uterine rupture include:

  • Sudden, severe abdominal pain (often described as tearing)
  • Cessation of uterine contractions
  • Loss of fetal heart sounds or fetal distress
  • Loss of uterine contour with easily palpable fetal parts through the abdomen
  • Presenting part retracts high (loss of station)
  • Minimal vaginal bleeding despite significant internal hemorrhage
  • Maternal shock (tachycardia, hypotension)

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Methergine (Option A) is contraindicated as it can increase uterine tone and worsen rupture.

Manual removal under GA (Option B) has already failed and risks further trauma.

Evacuation under GA (Option C) assumes intrauterine pathology, but with suspected rupture and inaccessible placental site, blind curettage is unsafe.

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for third degree perineal tear?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In precipitate labor, the entire process of labor and delivery is completed in less than 3 hours, often with forceful uterine contractions and lack of controlled delivery of the presenting part, leading to severe perineal trauma.

A third-degree perineal tear involves injury to the perineal muscles extending to the anal sphincter complex (external ± internal sphincter). These are classified under obstetric anal sphincter injuries (OASIS) and are most likely to occur when the fetal head passes rapidly through the birth canal, without giving the perineal tissues enough time to stretch.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Multiple pregnancy (Option A):

While it increases the risk of preterm labor or uterine overdistension, third-degree perineal tears are not directly associated with multiple gestations unless labor is rapid or delivery is instrumental.

Preterm delivery (Option B):

Preterm infants are smaller in size, reducing the likelihood of significant perineal trauma. In fact, preterm deliveries are generally protective against severe perineal tears.

Grand multipara (Option D):

Although uterine rupture and malpresentation risks are higher in grand multiparas, their perineal tissues are more stretched from previous deliveries, so perineal tears are less likely unless other risk factors are present (e.g., large baby, instrumental delivery).

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida patient had a delivery of a baby weighing 3.6kg. expulsion of placenta was also spontaneous and complete. Immediate after delivery of placenta there was continuous bleeding. Upon examination her pulse is 100 bpm, BP 110/70 mmHg, uterus is well contracted. Obstetrician performed an ultrasound which showed an empty uterus. What would be the most likely cause of bleeding in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely cause of bleeding in this clinical setting is genital tract trauma-such as vaginal lacerations, cervical tears, or episiotomy site bleeding. This is especially likely given the primigravida status and the large baby (macrosomia), both of which are risk factors for birth canal trauma during delivery.

Post-delivery, she develops continuous bleeding, but the uterus is well contracted, her vitals are stable, and ultrasound confirms an empty uterus. These findings rule out the two most common causes of postpartum hemorrhage (PPH): uterine atony and retained products of conception. (Option A and B)

An empty uterus on ultrasound rules out retained placenta or succenturiate lobe. (Option D)

questions.text: Perineal injury involving perineal skin, perineal muscle and both internal and external anal sphincter is known as:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Perineal tears are classified based on the extent of tissue involvement during vaginal delivery. A third-degree perineal tear involves injury to the perineal skin, perineal muscles, as well as disruption of the anal sphincter complex, which includes the external and internal anal sphincters.

choices.text: Dose of antibiotic and repair after initial workup
Antibiotics and delayed repair after 3 months
Conservative management and pelvic floor exercise

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman delivered at home five days ago and now presents to the gynecology outpatient department. On examination, the obstetrician finds a complete perineal tear (involving the anal sphincter complex and rectal mucosa), but there is no active bleeding. What is the best plan of management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This patient has presented five days postpartum with a complete perineal tear involving both the anal sphincter complex and rectal mucosa-classified as a fourth-degree perineal tear. Since there is no active bleeding and the injury is already several days old, immediate surgical repair is not advisable due to the risk of infection, tissue edema, and poor wound healing in the presence of contaminated and inflamed tissues.

The standard approach in such delayed presentations is to initiate a course of broad-spectrum antibiotics, provide local wound care, and allow the tissues to heal partially and inflammation to subside. Definitive elective surgical repair is planned after 6-12 weeks (commonly around 3 months) once the tissues are healthy, inflammation has resolved, and the patient is nutritionally and medically optimized. This improves the chances of successful anatomic and functional restoration of the perineum and anal sphincter.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Immediate repair under GA (Option A):

Not appropriate in delayed presentations, as infected or necrotic tissue may not hold sutures, and there is a higher risk of wound breakdown and complications.

Dose of antibiotic and repair after initial workup (Option B):

While antibiotics are necessary, early repair within days of injury is not recommended after the acute period unless done within the first 24 hours. At 5 days, delayed repair is preferred.

Conservative management and pelvic floor exercise (Option D):

This is insufficient for a fourth-degree tear, which requires surgical correction to prevent long-term complications like fecal incontinence and rectovaginal fistula.

questions.text: Identify site of hematoma in following image:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image demonstrates a deep pelvic collection above the level of the levator ani muscles, displacing surrounding structures, and possibly bulging into the vaginal fornices or broad ligament region. A supralevator hematoma occurs above the pelvic diaphragm and is usually due to injury to uterine or vaginal artery branches, especially during traumatic or instrumental deliveries. These hematomas may not be externally visible but can present with pelvic pain, hemodynamic instability, or a mass felt on bimanual examination.

A supralevator hematoma is a deep pelvic hematoma and must be suspected in postpartum women with persistent pain, hypotension, or pelvic mass despite a contracted uterus and no visible bleeding. It often requires imaging and surgical or radiologic intervention for management.

Explanation of Incorrect Options:

Vulvar hematoma (Option A):

Occurs superficially, involving the labia or perineum. It is typically visible externally as a swelling or discoloration of the vulva. The image in question would not show a deep pelvic collection if this were the case.

Infralevator hematoma (Option C):

Occurs below the levator ani muscles, often in the ischiorectal fossa or perineal region. It may present with painful perineal swelling but remains inferior to the pelvic diaphragm, unlike the image shown.

Cervical hematoma (Option D):

Would appear as a localized hematoma near the cervix or within the cervical canal. These are usually small and localized, and do not extend into the deep pelvic spaces.
